sn12.21:1.2: The purpose of this discourse (and the next) seems to be to extol dependent origination as a special insight of the Buddha. But it does so artlessly, simply plonking down a series of teachings without connecting them in any way. Editors and translators have tried to smooth it over, but I translate as-is. | The ten powers (of a Realized One) are explained at MN 12:9.1, where they are followed by the four kinds of self-assurance (MN 12:22.1). The powers are found independently at AN 10.21 and AN 10.22, and are claimed by Anuruddha at SN 52.15–24. The four kinds of self-assurance are at AN 4.8. | The “divine wheel” (brahmacakka) is a synonym for the “wheel of the teaching” (dhammacakka). In Śvetāśvatara Upaniṣad 1.6, the same term refers to the circle of existence in which all things live.
sn12.21:1.3: This is a recommended meditation (MN 10:38.4) leading to perfection (SN 12.23:1.4). In one place it exemplifies the Buddha’s teaching, but there it follows organically and is marked as quote (SN 22.78:2.2). Here it is simply pasted in after the previous passage. It does not offer an integration between the aggregates and dependent origination; they simply appear side by side.
sn12.21:1.8: This is the abstract principle of dependent origination; see discussion at SN 12.37:2.2. Again there is no textual link with the previous passages.
